meanings.def: if you nod, nod your head or your head nods, you move your head up and down to show agreement, understanding, etc.
examples: I asked him if he would help me and he nodded.
‘Ready?’ She nodded at me and we set off.
Her head nodded in agreement.
nod something He nodded his head sympathetically.
She nodded approval.
Everyone nodded their agreement.
‘That's exactly it,’ she said, nodding vigorously.
Ashamed, I could only nod.
He nodded absently, his mind obviously on other things.
He nodded with satisfaction.
She could not speak but just nodded mutely.
She nodded gently to herself.
She nodded in agreement.
She nodded sagely as she listened.
‘Is this the right way?’ she asked. The man nodded.
She nodded her approval.

meanings.def: to move your head down and up once to say hello or goodbye to somebody or to give them a sign to do something
examples: nod (to/at somebody) The president nodded to the crowd as he passed in the motorcade.
nod to/at somebody to do something She nodded at him to begin speaking
nod something (to/at somebody) to nod a greeting
Michael nodded a greeting to the other visitors.
She nodded to Duncan as she left.
He nodded curtly and walked away.
They nodded at us, so we nodded back.

meanings.def: to move your head in the direction of somebody/something to show that you are talking about them/it
examples: I asked where Steve was and she nodded in the direction of the kitchen.
She nodded towards his suitcase. ‘Going somewhere?’ she asked.
‘Let's go!’ he said, nodding towards/​toward the door.
Maria nodded towards the open door.

meanings.def: to let your head fall forward when you are sleeping in a chair
examples: He sat nodding in front of the fire.

idioms.idiom: have a nodding acquaintance with somebody/something

related: a nod is as good as a wink

meanings.def: a small quick movement of the head down and up again
examples: to give a nod of approval/agreement/encouragement
‘I couldn't have done this alone,’ he said with a nod towards/​toward his partner.
At a nod from Lawton, he gently turned the handle.
He dismissed them with a curt nod.
My teacher gave me a nod of reassurance and I began.
She answered with a slight nod of the head.
She answered with an almost imperceptible nod of the head.
She inspected my work and gave a satisfied nod.
a nod of approval
He gave a quick nod of recognition.

meanings.def: to be chosen for something; to be given permission or approval to do something
examples: He got the nod from the team manager (= he was chosen for the team).
The proposal should get the nod.
He's ready to play and just waiting to get the nod from the coach.

meanings.def: to give permission for something; to agree to something
examples: We've been given the nod to expand the business.
I hope he'll give the nod to the plan.

meanings.def: used to say that a suggestion or a hint will be understood, without anything more being said
examples: Everything could be done by a nod and a wink.

meanings.def: something that you do or say to acknowledge the importance or influence of something
examples: The house is white, in a passing nod to Greek tradition.
He gave a passing nod to the show that had launched his career.

meanings.def: if a proposal is accepted on the nod, it is accepted without any discussion
